p.s: In the following it is going to be analyzed the author's way of presenting his view on learning foreign languages with a focus on persuasive techniques and his use of language in his article.
To remember the article is about the small amount of people in theUK speaking foreign languages and the need of more education of learning other languages.
In the first two lines Worne describes UK's opinion about learning foreign languages very straight with treethree words (l. 1,2): can't, won't, don't.
In that two lines he uses inclusive language to clearly say to who he addresses his article, namely everyone living in the UK.
In the second and third paragraph he gives som researchable facts to the readers a picture of the small amount of interested people in learning foreign languages.

Especially in line 5: ... very little to suggest any prospect of us re-commissioning out collective brains, he uses inclusive language again to give his readers the feeling of being a part of this problem including himself as well.
Furthermore collective brains is a metaphor for their collective thinking.
In the fourth paragraph the author uses irony with his thrown in states which are in brackets for example in line 12-13: Everyone speaks English in the world of business (they don't).
The irony becomes clearly with the word Cobblers in line 15 and refers to the perfectly intelligent people (l. 12) just to say that those people are not smart.
In line 16-18 is an anaphora with the word language (l. 16) and the use of inclusive language again.
This anaphora puts the weight on the word language to give it importance.
This combined with the inclusive language and the numbering of some examples is creating a positive effect on his opinion which he tells in those two sentences.
Furthermore Worne gives his readers the point of view that foreign language is only for their advantage.
To give his opinion more weight he supports it with an another fact about the need of translators in UK companies because of not learning other languages which is almost two-thirds (l. 19).

Furthermore in line 22 he uses a hyperble: The problem is many UK businesses ave given up on home-grown talent and rely on translators of hire abroad, to give his readers a picture of UK's business communication with other countries.
In line 27 is a repetition with the word tough he points out how difficult todaystoday's reality and jobs are without learning a second or third language.
In the last two paragraphs Worne uses inclusive language again in combination with the words young people to mark out that the UK needs young human of his own country learning new languages.

Furthermore in the last paragraph he addresses it especially for the parents in the UK inclusing himself with inclusive language to motivate them to give their children the chance to learn a second language and make some intercultural experience and that he is doing it as well.

All in all he presents his point of view with naming negative aspects based on researchable facts and when he wants to address something to the UK he uses inclusive language to give his readers the feeling of being together and give them the feeling that they can change something together.
